title: Physical Security Controls
subtitle: Protecting the Foundation: Facility Security and Environmental Controls

prerequisites.title: Security Controls Fundamentals
prerequisites.why_needed: Physical controls are one of the four control categories

daily_tasks: Correlate badge events with network activity

introduction.hook: In 2019, a major financial services company discovered their sophisticated cyber defenses were meaningless when a contractor walked into their data center, plugged in a USB device, and walked out with gigabytes of customer data. The server room had no visitor logs, the badge system wasn't monitored, and USB ports hadn't been disabled. Physical security isn't just about locksâ€”it's the foundation upon which all other security controls depend.
learning_goals: Design layered physical security using defense-in-depth principles
Select appropriate access control mechanisms for different facility zones
Implement environmental controls to protect equipment and ensure availability
Recognize physical security threats and appropriate countermeasures
Integrate physical security with logical security controls

why_it_matters.career_impact: You'll assess facility security, recommend physical controls, and integrate physical and logical access systems.
why_it_matters.business_connection: Physical breaches can bypass all technical controls. Data center downtime from environmental failures costs thousands per minute.
why_it_matters.exam_relevance: Expect 4-6 questions on physical security controls, environmental protections, and facility security design.

sections.title: Physical Security Fundamentals and Defense in Depth

content.overview: Physical security protects personnel, hardware, software, data, and facilities. It addresses CIA objectives and uses multiple defensive layers.

mnemonics: PBIHS - Perimeter, Building, Interior, High-security, Secure areas (defense layers)
analogies: Like an onion with multiple layers - each layer an attacker must peel back

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Defense in depth: Perimeter â†’ Exterior â†’ Interior â†’ Secure â†’ High-security

key_points: Physical security addresses CIA like logical security
CPTED uses environmental design to deter crime
exam_tips: Focus on understanding concepts, not memorizing details
Expect scenario-based questions that test application of knowledge

knowledge_check.question: Which physical security layer should be addressed FIRST?
knowledge_check.explanation: Defense in depth starts at the perimeter. Perimeter controls (fencing, lighting, signage) deter and delay attackers before they reach buildings.

deep_dive.title: Physical Security Layers
deep_dive.content: Defense in depth applies physically: Perimeter (fencing, lighting, signage, guards), Building (access control, reception, mantraps), Floor/Zone (additional access control, cameras), Room (server room access, biometrics), Rack (rack locks, individual locks). Each layer should: Deter - make attack seem not worth it. Detect - identify intrusion attempts. Delay - slow attacker to enable response. Respond - activate when breach detected.

career_spotlight.career_path: Security Guard → Security Supervisor → Physical Security Analyst → Physical Security Manager

real_world_example.title: Twitter Office Break-In (2020)
real_world_example.incident: Attackers conducted physical and social engineering reconnaissance of Twitter offices before the account takeover attack. Gathered information about internal tools and procedures.
real_world_example.impact: Physical reconnaissance enabled social engineering attack. Demonstrated integration of physical and cyber attack planning.
real_world_example.lesson: Physical security is part of cybersecurity. Attackers combine physical and digital methods.

glossary_terms.definition: Layered security controls so breach of one layer doesn't compromise entire system
glossary_terms.exam_note: Applies to physical and logical security

glossary_terms.definition: Small room with two interlocking doors for controlled access
glossary_terms.exam_note: Prevents tailgating, one door must close before other opens

sections.title: Access Control Systems

content.overview: Physical access control determines who can enter specific areas and when, ranging from simple locks to sophisticated biometric systems.

mechanisms.function: Two interlocking doors - only one open at a time
Must badge OUT before badging IN again

what_would_happen_if.scenario: What if you didn't have anti-passback?
what_would_happen_if.consequence: Employees could share badges. One employee badges in, hands badge to friend through window, friend badges in with same card. No way to know who's actually in the building.

common_mistakes.correction: Mantrap = two doors (vestibule). Turnstile = single rotating barrier.

mnemonics: MATT - Mantrap, Anti-passback, Turnstile, Two-person integrity

key_points: Mantrap prevents tailgating with interlocking doors
Smart cards more secure than proximity (crypto)

knowledge_check.question: A data center requires two administrators to access the main server room. One administrator cannot open the door alone. What mechanism is this?
knowledge_check.explanation: Two-person integrity (dual control) requires two people to authenticate simultaneously. One person alone cannot open the door.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: Anti-passback prevents reusing a badge, not requiring two people
Mantraps prevent tailgating, not require multiple people
Time-based restricts WHEN, not WHO/HOW MANY

exam_tips: Know the three control categories: Technical, Administrative, Physical
Understand control functions: Preventive, Detective, Corrective, Deterrent, Compensating

deep_dive.title: Badge Technologies
deep_dive.content: Proximity cards (125 kHz) - low security, easily cloned with Proxmark. Smart cards (13.56 MHz) - use encryption, harder to clone but not impossible. Mobile credentials - phone as badge, can add additional factors. Multi-factor physical: Badge + PIN, Badge + Biometric. Badge cloning is real threat - layer with additional factors for sensitive areas.

career_spotlight.career_path: Facilities Technician → Access Control Admin → Physical Security Analyst → Security Manager

real_world_example.title: Pentest Badge Cloning
real_world_example.incident: During authorized physical pentest, testers cloned employee badge in parking lot using concealed Proxmark. Used cloned badge to access building, then server room.
real_world_example.impact: Demonstrated real-world badge cloning risk. Led to upgrade to smart cards and multi-factor for sensitive areas.
real_world_example.lesson: Standard proximity cards are easily cloned. Use smart cards or multi-factor for critical areas.

glossary_terms.definition: Contactless card for physical access using RFID technology
glossary_terms.exam_note: 125 kHz easily cloned; 13.56 MHz smart cards more secure

glossary_terms.definition: Authentication using physical characteristics (fingerprint, iris, face)
glossary_terms.exam_note: Something you are - hard to share/steal but has error rates

sections.title: Surveillance and Monitoring

content.overview: Surveillance systems provide visibility, deter unauthorized activity, and provide evidence for investigations.

must_remember_for_exam.fact: NVR = IP cameras; DVR = analog cameras
Dual-technology sensors reduce false alarms (require both triggers)

key_points: PTZ cameras offer flexibility; fixed cameras provide consistent coverage
NVR for IP cameras; DVR for analog

knowledge_check.question: Motion sensors are triggering false alarms from temperature changes. Which sensor type would BEST address this?
knowledge_check.explanation: Dual-technology requires BOTH PIR and microwave to trigger, filtering out single-factor false alarms like temperature changes.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: Higher sensitivity would INCREASE false alarms
Ultrasonic has different false alarm sources

exam_tips: Know the three control categories: Technical, Administrative, Physical
Understand control functions: Preventive, Detective, Corrective, Deterrent, Compensating

mnemonics: CCTV = Continuous Capture of Trespass Visuals
analogies: Surveillance is like a security guard that never sleeps and has perfect memory

deep_dive.title: Video Analytics
deep_dive.content: Modern CCTV systems add intelligence: Motion detection (reduce storage, enable alerts), Object detection (identify people, vehicles, weapons), Facial recognition (match against watchlists), Behavior analytics (detect loitering, wrong direction, package left behind), License plate recognition (LPR/ANPR). Privacy considerations: Employee monitoring laws, consent requirements, data retention policies. Analytics make cameras detective controls, not just recording.

career_spotlight.career_path: Security Guard → SOC Operator → SOC Supervisor → Security Operations Manager

real_world_example.title: Boston Marathon Bombing Investigation
real_world_example.incident: FBI identified bombing suspects within 3 days by reviewing thousands of hours of private and public surveillance footage. Crowdsourced image analysis helped.
real_world_example.impact: Demonstrated value of comprehensive surveillance for investigation. Led to increased camera deployments.
real_world_example.lesson: Surveillance is detective control - valuable for investigation. Retention policies must balance storage costs with investigation needs.

glossary_terms.exam_note: Detective control - monitors and records for review

glossary_terms.definition: Video Management System - software for managing surveillance cameras

sections.title: Environmental Controls

content.overview: Environmental controls protect equipment and ensure availability by maintaining appropriate conditions and protecting against hazards.

core_concepts.exam_critical: Online UPS = zero transfer time = best
Clean agents safe for people AND electronics. CO2 NOT safe for people.

what_would_happen_if.scenario: What if you used CO2 suppression in an occupied data center?
what_would_happen_if.consequence: CO2 displaces oxygen to extinguish fires. In an occupied space, this would also displace oxygen from people's lungs, causing suffocation. CO2 is only appropriate for unoccupied areas. Use clean agents (FM-200, Novec) in occupied spaces.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking all gas suppression is the same
common_mistakes.correction: Clean agents (FM-200) = safe for people. CO2 = NOT safe for people.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming wet pipe is best because it's fastest
common_mistakes.correction: Wet pipe damages electronics. Pre-action or clean agents are better for data centers.

mnemonics: Online = Obviously best (zero transfer), CO2 = Can't Occupy (dangerous to people)

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Clean agents (FM-200) = safe for electronics AND people
CO2 = NOT safe for people (suffocation risk)
VESDA = very early smoke detection via air sampling

key_points: Clean agents safe for people and electronics

knowledge_check.question: A data center needs fire suppression that won't damage servers and is safe for personnel. Which is MOST appropriate?
knowledge_check.explanation: FM-200 is safe for electronics (no residue) AND personnel (breathable). CO2 is dangerous to humans. Sprinklers damage electronics. Dry chemical leaves residue.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: CO2 suffocates people - dangerous in occupied areas
Dry chemical leaves residue damaging electronics

exam_tips: Know the three control categories: Technical, Administrative, Physical
Understand control functions: Preventive, Detective, Corrective, Deterrent, Compensating

deep_dive.title: Fire Suppression Systems
deep_dive.content: Water sprinkler: Cheap, effective, damages electronics. Clean agent (FM-200, Novec): Safe for electronics, expensive, environmental concerns. Inert gas (Argon, Nitrogen): Displaces oxygen, safe for electronics, requires sealed room. Pre-action: Water held back until confirmed fire - reduces false discharge damage. Data centers typically use clean agent or pre-action. Server rooms should have: Early warning (VESDA/smoke detection), suppression system, manual override, emergency power off.

career_spotlight.career_path: Data Center Technician → Senior Tech → DC Engineer → DC Manager → VP of Infrastructure

real_world_example.title: OVH Data Center Fire (2021)
real_world_example.incident: Fire destroyed one OVH data center in Strasbourg and damaged another. 3.6 million websites offline. Some customers lost data permanently due to backup co-location.
real_world_example.impact: €100M+ in damages. Major cloud provider offline for days. Customers learned importance of offsite backups.
real_world_example.lesson: Environmental controls can fail. Geographic backup distribution essential. Don't trust cloud provider to protect your data - you're responsible.

glossary_terms.definition: Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning - environmental control for temperature and humidity
Uninterruptible Power Supply - battery backup for power failures
glossary_terms.exam_note: Provides runtime for graceful shutdown or generator startup

sections.title: Physical-Logical Security Integration

content.overview: Integrating physical and logical security provides holistic visibility and enables advanced detection like impossible travel.

benefits: Single identity for physical and logical access
Detect impossible travel (badge in NYC, VPN from Moscow)

requirements: Visitor badges clearly different from employee badges

core_concepts.requirements: Clear workspace of sensitive documents when unattended

must_remember_for_exam.fact: Impossible travel = badge one location, login from distant location
Visitor badges should look different from employee badges
Clean desk policy = physical control for confidentiality

key_points: Integrate physical and logical for holistic visibility
Impossible travel detection catches credential compromise
Visitor badges must be visibly different
Clean desk is a physical security control

knowledge_check.question: An employee's VPN session originates from Germany at 2:00 PM, but their badge accessed US HQ at 1:30 PM. What does this indicate?
knowledge_check.explanation: This is impossible travel - physically impossible to be in both locations 30 minutes apart. Strongly indicates the credentials are compromised.

wrong_answer_analysis.why_wrong: Split tunneling affects routing, not geographic location
30-minute difference would require massive sync error
Badge was used at correct time - it's the VPN that's suspicious

exam_tips: Know OSI layers and which attacks target each layer
ARP poisoning is Layer 2; DNS poisoning is Layer 7 (application)

mnemonics: PACE: Physical Access Correlates with Electronic activity
analogies: Integration is like your phone knowing you're at home so it doesn't ask for verification
common_mistakes: Operating physical and logical security as separate silos

deep_dive.title: SIEM Integration for Physical Events
deep_dive.content: Correlating physical and logical events reveals threats: Badge access + VPN login from different locations = compromised credential. After-hours badge access + large file downloads = potential insider theft. Failed badge attempts + port scan from nearby IP = physical recon for cyber attack. Implementation: Send access control logs to SIEM, create correlation rules, integrate with identity management for context.

career_spotlight.career_path: Security Analyst → Converged Analyst → Senior Analyst → Security Fusion Center Manager

real_world_example.title: Physical Access in Cyber Attacks
real_world_example.incident: In multiple breaches, attackers gained physical access (as employee, contractor, or visitor) to plant rogue devices, steal credentials, or access systems directly. Target breach reportedly involved contractor credentials.
real_world_example.impact: Physical access bypasses many technical controls. Insider and physical threats enable cyber attacks.
real_world_example.lesson: Physical and cyber security must work together. Physical access events should trigger cyber investigation. Defense requires integrated approach.

glossary_terms.definition: Integration of physical and logical security under unified management
glossary_terms.exam_note: Enables holistic threat detection and response

glossary_terms.definition: Connecting related events from different sources to identify patterns
glossary_terms.exam_note: Physical + logical correlation detects complex attacks

hands_on_activity.title: Physical Security Assessment
hands_on_activity.objective: Evaluate physical security controls at a facility
hands_on_activity.scenario: Conduct a physical security assessment of NexaTech's new data center.
steps: Review each security layer from perimeter to rack
Identify control type (deterrent, preventive, detective, corrective)

exercises.recommendation: Add fence vibration sensors and CCTV
Add biometric authentication for high-security areas
Smart locks with access logging per rack

hands_on_activity.expected_outcome: Complete layered security assessment with actionable recommendations
reflection_questions: How does defense-in-depth apply to physical security?
What's more important: deterrence or detection?
How do you balance physical security with operational efficiency?

what_would_you_do.scenario: You're assessing physical security at DataVault's new data center. The building has badge access at the main entrance, but you observe: employees holding doors for others, cleaning staff using propped-open side doors, and server room badges working 24/7 for all IT staff.
what_would_you_do.context: The data center hosts financial and healthcare data for multiple clients. Compliance audits are scheduled next quarter.
what_would_you_do.question: What physical security issues do you prioritize?

options.text: Focus only on the server room - that's where the valuable data is
options.feedback: Defense in depth requires multiple layers. If outer layers fail, server room is the last defense. Tailgating and propped doors bypass all access controls.
options.consequences: Unauthorized person tailgates into building, accesses server room during off-hours using stolen badge.

options.text: Address all issues: anti-tailgating controls, eliminate propped doors, implement time-based server room access
options.feedback: Correct! Physical security requires layered controls. Anti-tailgating (mantraps, sensors), door prop alarms, and least-privilege time-based access all work together.
options.consequences: Multiple layers of control implemented. Attempted intrusion detected and stopped at building entry.

options.text: Install cameras everywhere - that will deter bad behavior
options.feedback: Cameras are detective controls, not preventive. They record incidents but don't stop them. You need controls that actually prevent unauthorized access.
options.consequences: Camera footage shows unauthorized access after the fact. Data already stolen.

options.text: Implement strict policies and train employees - technology can't fix behavior
options.feedback: Training alone is insufficient. Technical controls (mantraps, door sensors) enforce policy. People will take shortcuts without enforcement mechanisms.
options.consequences: Employees trained but continue holding doors for politeness. Policy exists but isn't enforced.

what_would_you_do.key_lesson: Physical security requires layered controls (defense in depth) and technical enforcement of policies. Training alone is insufficient - design systems that make violations difficult.
